author: Sally French
title: 5 of the wackiest integrations on team chat tool Slack
text:
Slack Slide 1 of 7 Gone are the days of boring, generic email. Since its launch in 2013, more companies are using team collaboration tool Slack (including the newsroom at MarketWatch).
The service is mostly a series of chat rooms, private groups and direct messages, but it also integrates with third-party services and supports community-built integrations.
Some of the integrations are clever takes on making work more efficient. The New York Times uses an intelligent bot on Slack to help decide which stories to post on social media. Another command called “/remind me to” allows Slack users to set reminders for themselves.
But some of the integrations are downright wacky.
From automating lunch delivery to letting you know whether the toilet is in use or not, here are some of the most creative and wacky ways companies are using Slack.
Getty Images Slide 2 of 7 Getting on-demand ice cream
Need to have an impromptu ice cream party for your team? A service called @large integrates with Slack as a personal assistant.
The Slackbot delivers users whatever they request (whether it’s a handyman, plane tickets, a resupply of snacks or even an order of ice cream) to @large on Slack. All the payment and delivery information is submitted upon sign-up, so users simply ask @large to bring what they need, and it will arrive as soon as possible.
Can you open your office door using @SlackHQ ? Yea.. I thought so.. #ThisisAndela #coolhacks #builtbyfellows pic.twitter.com/yIni3mAlEL
— Iyinoluwa Aboyeji (@iaboyeji) May 22, 2015 Unlocking your office door
Iyinoluwa Aboyeji, cofounder of Nigerian talent accelerator Andela, tweeted about a bot on Slack that opens your office door.
With Slack! “ @vibhu : Toilet Bot, found in the @houzz bathroom. pic.twitter.com/41nppCoG1l ”
— Harrison Weinerman (@hrrsn) April 20, 2015 Letting you know if there is a line for the bathroom
The bathroom at the offices of interior design site Houzz might have become the bathroom of the future through Slack. Twitter user @vibhu tweeted this “toilet bot” found in the house bathroom.
The stall has a door sensor and radio transmitter, which sends alerts to a channel on Slack called #toilet-bot that gives users notifications whenever the toilet becomes busy or available.
Sprig Slide 5 of 7 Personalized food delivery
Intelligent software builder site Skipflag created a Foodbot that takes each employee’s individual lunch order through Slack, to be delivered by food-delivery startup Sprig .
The Foodbot on Slack sends each team member a direct message with the day’s Sprig menu. Each employee has 20 minutes to enter their selection, and the bot takes the responses and automatically places an order with Sprig.
Panic/Slack Slide 6 of 7 Changing the color of the company sign
OS X and iOS app maker Panic Inc. constructed its first company sign that never stays the same color.
Color-customizable LEDs allow anyone to go to Panic Sign’s webpage to choose custom colors for the sign at that moment. The sign changes go into one of Panic’s Slack channels for review and documentation.
